titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V:45. Thursday— symbols drizzling—

Mr Graham came with a Land-grant to Alfred Flournoy, founded upon an Act of Congress passed a few days since, but in which the Sections which he had entered are incorrectly described, and one of them had already been granted to another person— I told him I could not sign the grant till the Act of Congress shall be amended— Governor Barbour brought the list of Officers to be nominated for promotion with Coll. Jones’s name upon it, signed by him— And I sent the nomination to the Sent— Jones himself came to argue his claim to me, after I had decided it in his favour— Mr Tomlinson came with the Colonial Trade Bill which has passed the Senate and is now before the House of Representatives— The last Section, introduced by Woodbury, if he understood it himself was a trap— Mr Tomlinson however did not understand it as I did— He had an amendment, which he intended to propose to the house; and with which the Bill will be as effective as I expected could be accomplished— But I told him if the House passed Woodbury’s Section, I hoped they would fully understand what it meant— Mr Johnson the member from Virginia, introduced his brother, and a Mr Leffler, of his Constituents— Governor Barbour called again, with a Letter from Governor Troup of Georgia, in answer to the missive by Lieutenant Vinton, setting the authority of the United States at defiance; accompanied with an Order for reserving the Surveyors who may be arrested, for indicting the Officers of the United States who may arrest them—and for two Divisions of the Militia of the State to be in readiness to resist hostile invasion— I desired Governor Barbour to give notice to the members of the Administration to meet here to-morrow Morning— Mr Seymour came to recommend remissions of penalties, in behalf of two or three persons in Vermont. Mr Gurley to recommend a Mr Turner as Surveyor General in Louisiana, under a Bill expected to pass— Mr Southard and Mr Clay to enquire of the advices from Georgia— Mr Clay spoke also of the Instructions to be sent to Mr Poinsett, on the conditional Ratification of the Treaty with Mexico— Mrs Adams was quite unwell all day, and in the Evening very ill—
2— V— symbols Cloudy.

Cabinet Meeting— The question was whether the communications received yesterday from Governor Troup of Georgia, and Lieutenant Vinton, should be communicated to Congress; and if so, whether with any comment upon their character— That they should be communicated the opinion was unanimous. Mr Rush and Mr Wirt inclined to the opinion that some remarks should at the same time be made to disclaim the intention of an immediate resort to armed force, which Troup affects to consider as declared in the Secretary of War’s Letter to him— Mr Clay urged that the simple transmission of the papers without a word of commentary would be advisable— My own first thought was to shew by a very summary exposure the prevarication of Troup; but I soon came to the conclusion that the proper treatment of it was silence— I sent the Message with the Copies. Mr Knight of the Senate and Mr Forward of the House brought me several Bills to sign— I told them, I would go in the Evening to the Capitol— Coll. Dwight called, and returned me the copies of my two Accounts that I had given him to explain the charges upon which Ingham had invidiously commented in the House— E. Everett came, and shewed me an additional paragraph to the Report of the Committee of the House, to be made tomorrow, upon the Messages concerning Georgia— He said he would move that the Message I should send this day should be referred to the same Committee, and it was so done— Mr Condict came from the New-Jersey Delegation to recommend Coll. Aaron Ogden for a Commissioner under the Act for distributing the Slave indemnities—and Pearce came to press Wheaton for the same appointment— At 7 this evening I rode with my two Sons to the Capitol— Messrs. Clay, Rush, Barbour and Southard were there to assist me in reading Bills, till ten or eleven. I remained there till two in the Morning, and signed about forty Bills— One only of which gave me pleasure, as permanently beneficial—half a Million appropriated yearly for the gradual improvement of the Navy— It was saved from a local quicksand, with extreme difficulty— I sent to the Senate, my last Message of nominations— At two in the Morning they suspended their rule of presenting no Bills to the President, on the last day of the Session; determining to send all Bills they could pass till Noon—and adjourned— I came home, at half past two.
3. VII:30— Close of 19. Congress 2— Session—

At eleven this morning I walked to the Capitol having previously received several visitors— Mr Betton is an old man who brought many recommendations for an appointment as Agent to the Creek Indians— He has already been employed among them, in the distribution of the money payable to them by Treaty— Genl. Harrison, introduced his Son-in Law Esty, and Judge Burnett, both from Ohio— Taliaferro, Little, and Gurley members of Congress came to take leave— The 3— Ingersoll’s2— Markoe’s, and Bayard were visitors from Philadelphia— Dr Staughton the Son, introduced Mr Costerizan and Mr Rebeyre, Silk manufacturers of Lyon in France, who have the project of emigrating to this Country, and setting up the manufacture at Philadelphia— I recommended to the Doctor to introduce them to Mr Rush who is much engaged in researches upon this subject, concerning which he has to prepare a Report for Congress— At the Capitol where I continued until the adjournment of Congress, I had only five or six Bills of little importance to sign— The Colonial Trade Bill was lost by a disagreement between the two Houses— The House of Representatives having last Evening adhered to an Amendment the Senate this morning adhered to their non concurrence with it— The Loan and Woollen Bills were left among the unfinished business— The current appropriation Bills for all the Departments have been liberal enough—but the only Bill which I consider as a permanent benefit to the Nation, and creditable to the Congress just expired is the Bill for the gradual improvement of the Navy— Stripped as it was of half its worth, by the exclusion from it of a Naval Academy, which the Bill from the Senate had provided for. A local interest of New-York, struggling for a third dry Dock, came last Evening within a hairs breadth of losing the Bill— Mr Storrs was induced only by personal intreaty from me to give up the point— The Seneca Indian conveyance, was laid on the table by the Senate. Though I sent for, and spoke with Mr D. B. Ogden, concerning it— About 4. S. Bell and W. H. Harrison of the Senate B. Bassett and D. Webster of the House came as a joint Committee to announce their readings to close the Session—to which I assented— Walked home— Mr Southard with me— T. Newton came in the Evening and took leave—
4. V:30.— Post-Office— Sun rose 5:57:35 = 6:22

Heard at Mr Baker’s Church, Mr Stewart, one of the Missionaries to the Sandwich Islands from Acts 26:18—“To open their eyes, and to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan unto God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins, and inheritance among them which are sanctified, by faith that is in me”— He gave a very particular and minute account of the success of the Missionaries from this Country at the Sandwich Islands— The first Mission there was in 1820. and the Islanders till then were in the primitive barbarism of the Savage State— The details of their manners were horrible and disgusting— Treachery and Cruelty; Parricide and Infanticide were among their most ordinary practices—they are now more than half civilized— Many thousands have learnt to read and write, observe the Sabbath, and have the gospel preached to them—

On returning from Church I found Mr Everett and Miss Brooks on a visit to Mrs. Adams— Afterwards C. J. Ingersoll and Joseph R. Ingersoll called upon me— Very anxious to obtain a Midshipman’s warrant for a young kinsman of theirs named Wilcocks— Charles Ingersoll had spoken of him to me, two years since, and now claimed of me something like the performance of a promise, into which he construed some general expression of kindness with which I received his solicitation— I now rectified this pretension by assuring him that I had made no promise, and never made any of Appointments which must be determined by the Heads of Departments, acting by certain indispensable rules; but said I would solicit the Appointment by the Secretary of the Navy. C. J. Ingersoll told me, he had just lost his youngest Son—

Afternoon, I heard Mr Hawley, from Romans 12.2 “And be not conformed to this world”—and in the Evening, Mr Little from Revelations 14.6–7. “And I saw another Angel fly in the midst of Heaven, having the everlasting gospel to preach unto them that dwell on the earth, and to every Nation, and kindred, and tongue, and people—saying with a loud voice, fear God, and give glory to him: for the hour of his judgment is come; and worship him that made heaven, and earth, and the sea, and the fountains of waters”— I called at the Post-master General’s to see D. P. Cook, who is there ill, but he was asleep— R. Letcher of Kentucky, and P. Sprague of Maine; called and took leave of me in the Evening.
5. V— symbols Sun rose veiled

Of the forty visitors whose names are in the margin about one half are members of Congress who came to take leave before their departure homeward. Sherer, came from sheer curiosity—native of New-Hampshire successively transplanted to New-York, Pennsylvania, and Virginia, he is returning to his fathers in Pennsylvania, and taxed my curiosity with a long half hour before breakfast— Dougherty came for a place, to superintend some of the public works— Markley, Ogden, Breese, M’Carty and Wheaton, came to thank me for the appointments they have received— Knapp, Allen, Love. P. Adams, to apply for Office or money— Allen is a mendicant Clergyman, who was here last Summer. He has the manners of a half-idiot— Lowry brought me a Resolution of the Senate, and the confirmation of all my recent nominations— Pleasonton had a Letter from Satterlee Clarke, asking questions which I advised him to decline answering— Clowes came with an invention of his own and begging for charity— Thomas told me that he remained here this day to see Mr Clay, with whom Dr Watkins had undertaken to reconcile him. He said also that it was his intention to take a more active part in the measures of the Senate at the next Session, than he had done heretofore— Taylor spoke with very little hope and less Confidence in the delegation from New-York at the present Congress— The western members who called this morning, and again in the Evening are in far higher Spirits— I was from ten this morning till ten at Night never five minutes without one or more of these marginal Notes— And I can scarcely conceive a more harassing, wearying, teazing condition of existence— It literally renders life burdensome: What retirement will be, I cannot realize, but have formed no favourable anticipation— It cannot be worse than this perpetual motion, and crazing cares— The weight grows heavier from day to day— Mr Clay says that these times of trouble, are the times which try the Spirits of men— Even so— And may our strength be proportioned to the ordeal through which we must pass.
6. V. symbols Sun rose veiled.

A Cabinet Meeting had been appointed for this day at one O’Clock. Mr Wirt called early to say that he was much engaged with public Causes at the Supreme Court and asked, if he could be excused from attending here— I told him I could not dispense with his attendance; and he came— Varnum introduced Abel Harris of Portsmouth New-Hampshire, who came to solicit the appointment of Naval Officer there, when vacant— The death of the incumbent, Hall, is expected shortly. Bowen came to borrow money to buy a horse, instead of one he has lost by falling into a Well— Ruggles, Hendricks, Marks and Orr, are members of Congress who came to take leave. Cabinet Meeting at one— The question was whether a proclamation shall be issued, conformably to the Act of Congress of March 1823. to regulate commerce with the British Colonial Ports— There was much discussion upon the point, whether the proclamation was imperatively required by the Law—whether the time for issuing the proclamation was at the Discretion of the President, and whether he can suspend its operation, till the first of October, or of January next. Mr Clay thought that the issuing of the Proclamation was positively required by the Law; but that the time was to some extent discretionary, and that its operation might be prospectively made. He said Mr Vaughan, the British Minister had called on him yesterday, and requested that if the Proclamation should issue, it might be with some previous notice— I thought there could be no prospective suspension of the Law by the executive; but that it might be effected by remission of the forfeitures, until reasonable time of notice shall be given— There was a question whether the trade had been prohibited by the British Laws, so that the Proclamation would be required, and concluded that it had— Mr Clay said that Judge Thompson of the Supreme Court was of that opinion— After three hours of deliberation it was agreed to meet again next Monday before a final decision should be made— Dr. Wallace called after dinner, having passed the Winter at Philadelphia; in attendance upon anatomical dissections— He repeated his advice to me to abandon the practice of river bathing— I wrote a little this Evening; but overpowered with weariness, retired about ten, for the Night—
7— V— symbols Cloudy.

Mr Sanford a Senator from New-York, called and I had conversation with him concerning the Treaty deed of the Seneca Indians to R. Troup, Ogden and Rodgers, which I sent to the Senate, and which they retained without acting upon it— It seems they propose to make a Georgia question of it—whether the Government of the United States have properly any agency in the matter— Sanford said it would be fully discussed at the next Session of the Senate— Mr M’Lean the Postmaster General came with the Petition and papers in the case of a person named Doolittle, a Clerk in a Post-Office in Vermont, who took money from a Letter, and is under indictment for it upon his own Confession— As he made the disclosure, under a rebuke of Conscience, is repentant, and bears otherwise a good character, his friends are anxious that a Noli Prosequi should arrest the trial, rather than take a pardon upon conviction. I desired Mr M’Lean to direct the District Attorney in Vermont to discontinue the prosecution— John Williams of Tennessee called before his departure to return home— He spoke of Governor Carroll, General Jackson, Felix Grundy, and G. W. Campbell— Mrs Royall brought a copy of her new novel The Tennesean and said she heard I was to be ousted, but then I should be as worthy after it as before— Scott the late Member from Missouri came to take leave— Said he was perfectly satisfied with the appointment of Eskridge as Judge, and of Beverley Allen as Attorney in Missouri; and that he should go home entirely contented. Dr Sewall came and invited me to attend the Medical Commencement of the Columbian College, at Noon to-morrow; which I promised if not otherwise engaged— Richard Peters called with a youth named Bolivar, a nephew of the Colombian Libertador, who has been four years studying at Philadelphia, and is now going to the University of Virginia— Peters comes to ask for the appointment of Reporter to the Supreme Court in place of Wheaton— Frye came to say he found it would not be necessary to concentrate in one person all the Land titles in the Heirs of Joshua Johnson— Company to dine— Bartlett, Bayard, Bolivar, Frye, Joseph R. and A. W. Ingersoll M’Lean Markoe’s, two. Peters, Sanford, SouthardStewart, Taylor, Dr Wallace, Webster, Wheaton and John Williams— Judge Burnett Miss Brooks, Mr and Mrs Everett, Mr Este, and C. J. Ingersoll did not come— In the Evening I was idle— Johnson Hellen went on Monday to Rockville: to attend the County Court.
8. V:45— symbols Sun rose 5:50:10 = 6:17.

Columbian College, Medical Commencement; at the Unitarian Church at noon, which I attended— The house was nearly full—many Ladies present— The Revd. Obadiah Brown introduced the solemnities with prayer, and Dr Sewall in the absence of Dr Staughton, the President of the Columbian College, delivered a written address, and then conferred degrees of Doctor of Medicine upon seven pupils of the College— After which Dr delivered another written Address, and there were sundry symphonies from the organ— The whole occupied about an hour and a half— Returning home I met Mr. Martindale; a member of the House from New-York, who had called to take leave— I found also on my table a card from Lewis Williams of North-Carolina, who had done the same— Mr David B. Ogden who has been attending at the Supreme Court, likewise came in to say that he was about returning home to New-York— Mr Stewart introduced Mr Everts, as the Secretary to the Missionary Society— He spoke of the Message upon the concerns with Georgia, about the Indians, as having been generally satisfactory to the part of the Country from which he came—that is, Boston— Elton and Garrett were two young men; Strangers, from Philadelphia, who came to see me, from mere curiosity. Ironside came for a copy of a paper written by Mr Clay, which I had not seen. Governor Barbour brought a bundle of recommendations for a Superintendent of the Cumberland Road— I left it to him to decide between M’Lure who had been Superintendent before, and a Mr Krebs, recommended by half the Pennsylvania Legislature, and about twenty members of Congress— The Governor spoke also of measures to be taken with Coll. Brearley, the Agent appointed to accompany the emigrating Creeks, to go westward of the Mississippi— He is not satisfied with Brearley and hears bad accounts of him— Proposes to give him peremptory orders, which I recommended— Mr Tomlinson called in the evening to take leave— Going to-morrow Morning— He is nominated by the Republicans of Connecticut for the Office of Governor of that State the ensuing year— He has been one of the most respectable and worthy members of Congress for six years, and his loss here is much to be regretted— I was sleepless last Night, the consequence of which was that I was this Evening disqualified for writing—
9. VI:15. symbols Sun rose fog-veiled—

Mr Graham called with a list of eight Clerks in the General Land Office, four of whom he was under a necessity of dismissing; and as he could not take upon him to make a selection he proposed to let them draw lots to determine which of them should remain, and which should go out— I spoke to him of the Letter I had received from the Senators and Representatives from the State of Alabama, requesting that no Sales of relinquished Lands in that State should be made this year— They had a Bill before Congress for the new regulation of this subject, but it did not work through— In other States where there are relinquished Lands, Graham said the Delegations were desirous that the Sales should be made, and he added that it would be of some importance to the Revenue. Mr Handy came to ask indulgence for the debt due from the Presbyterian Church to me— He said they were much pressed to pay the debt to Mrs Meigs, and I told him I wished them to discharge that before thinking of mine— He said they had much increased in numbers, but not in wealth— William Lee, third Auditor and R. Cutts—second Comptroller came to speak of the claims of the Staff Officers residing here for arrears of double rations. Cutts left with me a number of papers concerning it— Mr Little came to solicit a continuation of employment in recording the Patents at the Patent-Office— There was a Bill passed the House of Representatives making appropriations for two recording Clerks at the Patent Office; but for want of time failed in the Senate— Livingston came to take leave—and shewed me a miniature of his daughter painted by Inman— Mr Marks introduced Mr. M’Millan a member of the Legislature of Virginia— Clarke, brought a Report of a Committee of the House of Representatives, upon complaints against District Attornies— Referred by the House to the President. Mr Clay spoke of his appointment of Clerks—Fendall, Vail, and a young Pennsylvanian— S. L. Knapp omitted, but to be Editor of Force’s paper— Judge Hay and Mr Southard met here in the morning and dined with me— Southard spoke of his preparations for commencing the execution of the Act for the gradual improvement of the Navy— The dry Docks at Gosport and Charlestown— The purchase of timber for seasoning— The nurseries for Live-Oak—and the Railway, at Pensacola— Baldwin is to be immediately employed.
10. V: symbols Sun rose cloud-veiled.

Mr Wethers is a Patentee, who came with a formal written complaint against Dr Thornton, which he had already exhibited to the Secretary of State— Mr Clay declined acting upon it, considering the causes of complaint alledged as pertaining to the private, and not the official character of Dr Thornton— I was of the same opinion and told Withers, that if wronged, his remedy was before the judicial tribunals— When judge Johnson last dined with me, he had promised took look into the Act of Congress of 30. March 1802. “to regulate trade and intercourse with the Indian tribes, and to preserve Peace on the frontiers”— The act upon which the prosecution of the Georgia Surveyors within the Indian Territory has been directed— The judge now suggested that there might be a Constitutional difficulty, in the execution of the Law— For which he referred to the Constitution—Article 3. Sect: 2. last paragraph: and to the 6th. Article of Amendment to the Constitution—securing to Criminals, a trial, in the State and District where the Crime was committed—whence Judge Johnson anticipates two objections to his jurisdiction in this Case—first, if the Survey is admitted to have been within the State of Georgia, it will be contended that Congress could pass no Act prohibiting Surveys by authority of the State, and secondly, that Alabama claims the very Land where these Surveys were made—and if her claim be correct, the trial by the sixth Amendment to the Constitution must be in Alabama— I said I supposed the Georgia Surveyors would be estopped from pleading that they were surveying in the State of Alabama— The judge appeared very desirous of being relieved from trying the Cause, and said there could be no possible reliance upon a Georgia Jury to try it— But he said he should take occasion as soon as possible to send it for trial to the Supreme Court—and he said he had decided many years ago the principle that Indian territory was not within the civil Jurisdiction of the United States. Barton and Cook came to take leave— Cook is convalescent, but much emaciated— I desired Mr Brent to ask Mr Clay, if he had not occasion to send a special agent to the Havanna— Mr Marks came to introduce a Mr Denny from Pittsburg. Peters goes to-morrow for Philadelphia—much mortified at the appointment of Markley, as Naval Officer at Philadelphia— General Brown informed me of his intention of making a tour Southward as far as New-Orleans to return by the Western Country—
Heard Mr Little this morning, from Luke 11–4— “And forgive us our sins; for we also forgive every one that is indebted to us.”
Afternoon, at Mr Baker’s, from Matthew 5–8. [“]Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God.”

In the Evening, Mr Little again from James 1.26.27. “If any man among you seem to be religious, and bridleth not his tongue, but deceiveth his own heart; this man’s religion is vain— Pure religion, and undefiled before God and the Father is this, To visit the fatherless and widows in their affliction, and to keep himself unspotted from the world.” Mr Little has finished or suspended his Evening Historical Lectures, and now preaches benevolence, brotherly love and sincer. . . religion morning and evening— He was this evening severely sarcastic upon the seeming religious man who bridleth not his tongue; and began his discourse by the remark that Religion is like money—those who had the least of it, talked the most about it—

Count Lucchesi, Consul General from the two Sicilies and from the Pope, came at two O’Clock, and took leave of me— He has received a new Appointment, as Charge d’Affaires of the king of the Sicilies, at the Court of Brazil; and is going to New-York there to wait the arrival of his Successor in this Country, which he expects in May; and then to embark for Rio de Janeiro. He expressed much regret at the prospect of leaving this Country, and thought he should take much less pleasure in a residence in Brazil than in this Country— Much of this I have no doubt was a form of civility—

Mr Campbell after the service notified a meeting of the Pew-holders and members of Mr Bakers Church to attend there a meeting at Noon to-morrow, to determine upon the measures to be taken for the support of the Pastor— The lot of dismission from the General Land-Office has fallen upon him; and Mr Campbell gave notice, that upon the issue of the Meeting to-morrow would depend the question whether Mr Baker could continue with the Church or not—

After the Evening service, I returned home, and wrote to my Son George from whom I received also a Letter. I was occupied too in signing Land-grants till near Midnight— Johnson Hellen returned last Evening from Rockville
Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen dined with us below— Mary has been for weeks and Mrs Adams all winter confined to their chambers.
12. VI:45. symbols Cloudy— Rain

Mr Graham brought me to sign three Proclamations for the sale of relinquished Lands— It remains to be determined whether those in Alabama should be sold, or reserved, as the whole delegation from the State, in both Houses of Congress— Mr Graham says the postponement of the Sales will materially affect the revenue of the year— Mr Wirt called to say that he should be necessarily engaged at the Supreme Court this day, and thus unable to attend the Cabinet Meeting, at one O’Clock— Coll. Jones came, chiefly to recommend G. H. Scott, for Superintendent of the Repairs on the Cumberland Road— I referred him to the Secretary of War, but observed I believed the choice was already made— Cabinet Meeting from one to half past four— The question upon issuing a Proclamation, under the act of Congress of 1. March 1823. was again discussed, and Mr Canning’s Notes to Mr Gallatin of 28 and 29. January were read— It was obvious that the British Government would adhere to their determination not to negotiate, on the subject of this trade, and whatever discretion the Executive might possess, to choose the time for issuing the Proclamation, it was unanimously concluded, that it could not with propriety be delayed so long as until the next Session of Congress; and that if delayed now, no adequate motive for issuing it could be assigned, at any subsequent Period before the Session— I requested Mr Clay to prepare a draught of the Proclamation, to be presented at a further Meeting, at ten O’Clock, the day after to-morrow, when the Attorney General may be able to attend— On examination of the Act of 1. March 1823—it was the prevailing ultimate opinion, that the exclusion of British vessels coming from the Colonies would take effect only from the time of its publication; and that there might be a remission of the forfeiture to vessels arriving without previous notice of the exclusion— Mr Clay said he had seen Mr D. P. Cook, and offered him the secret Agency at the Havana, which the Circumstances of the present time render peculiarly expedient, and which he has accepted— He proposes to embark immediately— Mr Southard, and Mr M’Lean the Postmaster General had earnestly urged this appointment— Evening spent in writing.
13. V:40. symbols Sun rose cloud-veiled.

Mr King the Painter came to ask me to lend him the Portrait of my father, by Stewart, which have here; and I agreed that he should send for it to-morrow, and keep it some time— He has already the Portrait of A. H. Everett by Girard, which Everett sent me— King says that he prefers the English to the French Style of Painting, and thinks there are now three or four Portrait Painters in England, who would have surpassed this work of Girard. Captain M’Neill came with certain papers and a claim of double Rations; by appeal from the decision of the Secretary of War against him— I took his papers for examination— Scott came again with an imploring solicitation for a place—any place, to give bread to a family of 13. children— Fleet Smith is a lawyer; who came to ask for the appointment of Judge, of the Orphans Court for the County of Washington; vacated yesterday, by the decease of Richard Bland Lee— I received also several written recommendations for various persons to fill the same place— Mr Wheaton came to tender his thanks for the appointment of Charge d’Affaires to Denmark; though asking time, three or four months to consider of it— To publish the Volume of his Reports containing the present term of the Supreme Court—to finish a Volume of the revised Statute Book of N-York upon which he is occupied; and to consult his father who is far advanced in years and may perhaps object to his leaving this Country— I told him the time of his departure might be accommodated to his own convenience— Cook is going to Norfolk there to embark on a secret Agency at the Havana— He has been dangerously ill, and looks consumptive, but recoverable— Mr Southard brought the papers of a Court of Inquiry upon Captain Smith of the Marines at New-York, and charged by Captain Kuhn, against Coll. Henderson— Mr Vaughan came at one, and delivered to me a Letter from the King of Great Britain, announcing the decease of his brother the Duke of York— Mr Bulfinch came again to ask my influence with the Secretary of the Navy to obtain an appointment as a Clerk in that Department— Dr Thornton brought three pair of Suspenders of which I selected one, from a Mr Horn the inventor— Mr Brent brought Commissions to Rochester, and J. Speed Smith to sign; and Instructions to D. P. Cook— Judge Cranch called in the Evening, and left with me his Discourse on the character of my father, which he expects to deliver next Friday Morning at half past nine or ten, before the Columbian Institute.

div.p: 14. V— symbols Sun rose veiled— Snow— Cloud— Clear.

Cabinet Meeting at 10— Mr Clay had sent me yesterday a draught of a Proclamation, declaring, that the trade and intercourse between the United States, and Certain British Colonies, which had been opened by an Act of Parliament of June 1822. was now prohibited by two Acts of Parliament of 5. July 1825 and an Order in Council of 27. July 1826— I had made some slight alterations in the draught, and abridged it by one half. Some further alterations were made, and it was determined that it should be issued, to-morrow or the next day— I also requested Mr Rush to prepare circular Instructions to the Collectors of the Customs; for carrying into effect the Navigation Acts of 1818 and 1820. There was some question whether the interdict upon British shipping from the Colonies, will not upon the issuing of the proclamation, operate retrospectively to the first of December last, the time at which the British Prohibition commenced, but I think the Law fairly susceptible of the Construction—that our interdict shall commence only upon and after the issuing of the Proclamation— The meeting was abridged, as Mr Wirt was engaged at the Supreme Court, in the argument, of a Cause, and Mr Barbour and Mr Southard, were to take the Steam-boat at four this afternoon, upon a tour to Point-Comfort and Norfolk— Mr Rush remained with me, perhaps two hours after the Meeting was over, and we conversed together on this thorny subject of the Colonial Trade; upon which he urged me to write for publication— I intend so to do, if I can command the necessary time— Mr Clay came in before Rush left me, and spoke of a draught he had some time since submitted of an Instruction to Poinsett, to propose to the Mexican Government the purchase of the Province of Texas to the Rio del Norte, or the Colorado— I asked him to let me see the draught again— Mr Catlett of Alexandria made me an Evening visit; and Judge Cranch came and took his manuscript Eulogy, upon the Character of my father, which I had read, and upon which I had made sundry remarks— It is to be delivered on Friday morning next before the Columbian Institute— I finished this day the signing of 1725 Land-grants, sent to me from the Land-Office on the 9th. Also 5 Virginia Military Land-warrants.

div.p: 15. VI— Columbian College— Sun rose beclouded—

Varied my morning walk, from the Capitol Square to the College Hill; the distance being the same— Mr Anderson the Comptroller called this morning, to converse with me upon the Circular Instruction to the Collectors to be sent with the Proclamation— He spoke also of other subjects; and particularly of the bitter and rancorous spirit of the Opposition— It has produced during the late Session of Congress four or five Challenges to duels, all of which however happily all ended in smoke—and at a public dinner given last week to John Randolph of Roanoke a toast was given, directly instigating assassination. Mr Anderson remarked to me, that General Jackson was deeply indebted to me for his character before the Nation, and thought I had been ill requited for kindness and service to him— Dr Todson came in while Mr Anderson was with me, and solicited a remission of that part of the Sentence of the Court-Martial upon him, which required the payment by him of 47. dollars; to which I assented. I directed him to call at the War Department, where the order would be given. Major C. J. Nourse, now the Chief Clerk of the Department, afterwards came over and I desired him to enter the remission of that part of the Sentence, upon the proceedings of the Court— He also left with me a Letter of remonstrance from another Officer cashiered by Sentence of a Court-Martial—J. B. Triplett, with other papers concerning it— Mr Reed, late a Senator from the State of Mississippi called to take leave— His Son, a West Point Cadet was with him— Mr Chase, a Son of the late Judge Chase came to solicit the appointment of judge of the Orphan’s Court vacated by the death of Richard Bland Lee— Chase is now a Messenger in the Navy Commissioners Office— I directed the Commission of judge to be issued to him. Mr Hall came to ask for the same place; but it was too late— Mr Clay and Mr Rush were here together— Rush had the draught of his Circular to the Collectors, which was discussed and amended, and which is to be prepared for publication with the Proclamation on Saturday— Mr Clay told me he should send his Son as a Messenger with despatches to Mexico. He read his Instruction to Poinsett to propose the purchase of Texas— I advised him to leave out the offer of Ships of War, and offer only money. Mr and Mrs Everett, and Miss Brooks—Mr D. Webster, and Mr J. Bartlett dined and spent the Evening with us. There was a Mr Washington came, to ask the return of the papers sent by Captain Gustavus Harrison— I gave him the papers and advised him to recommend to Harrison as a friend, more attention to the discharge of his duties—
16. V. Sun rose 5:35 = 6:6— Behind South East Treasury Chimney.

Immediately after Breakfast, at half past nine I walked to the Capitol, and in the Apartment of the Columbian Institute heard the Discourse upon my father’s character, delivered by Judge Cranch— It was nearly three hours in the delivery; yet a considerable part of it, he omitted— The Style of composition was plain and simple—the assemblage of facts more copious and diversified than in any of the Eulogies, I had heard before; and there were in several of the extracts from writings of my father, in the Letter from Mr Jefferson to him on the death of my Mother, and in several of the allusions to her a pathos, which affected every hearer, and which more than once moved me, to the very borders of manhood— There was a vote of the Institute of thanks to judge Cranch, and that the Discourse should be printed for their use— The company assembled was not numerous, and consisted about one half of Ladies— The Meeting adjourned about one, and I walked home, in company with Mr Daniel Brent and Dr Watkins— At the gate of my house, I met Mr Rush who went up with me to my Chamber— He had the amended draught of a Circular to the Collectors of the Customs, to be sent with the Proclamation relating to the British Colonial trade— It was approved, and will be printed and forwarded tomorrow— Mr Daniel Brent brought a draft of an Instruction to J. Sergeant and Joel R. Poinsett, Ministers to Tacubaya, which I approved— Young Elliot came to ask if I would take some additional copies of Judge Cranch’s discourse, of which I ordered a dozen— My Son John dined at Mr Rush’s— Charles declined, and is unwell with a swollen face— I have also a cold, falling upon my lungs—I received a Letter from Dr Todsen, of thanks for the remission of the pecuniary part of his Sentence; a flattering Latin quotation from Cicero; and a renewed solemn protestation of his Innocence— After examining and approving the Lead mine Leases sent from the Ordnance and War Department, I passed the remainder of the Day and Evening in reading public Papers and in writing— Letters to Charles Carroll of Carrollton— Elkanah Watson—and this page—
17— V. symbols Sun rose V:33:30 = 6:5. behind S.E. Treasy Chimney.

Captain M’Neill came for a decision upon his claim for double rations—by an appeal from the Secretary of War— I told him that however reasonable his claim might be, and however disposed I was to comply with his wish, I had no authority to do so— Tyler came and introduced Bocciardi, a native of Paris; son of an Italian Sculptor, who he said wrought the marble horses at the entrance of the Thuileries— He has been residing more than twenty years in North-Carolina; and is now about returning to France— Mr Rush called to mention that Mr Pleasonton had complained to him, of two Clerks in his Office, who upon a political dispute yesterday had fallen to a boxing match, and as he could not ascertain who struck the first blow, he was disposed to dismiss them both. I said that might be necessary if it could not be shewn who commenced the fray; but otherwise it would be very hard to punish the assaulted as severely as the assailing party— He said he would make further enquiry— He came afterwards again and introduced Mr Todd a lawyer of Philadelphia— Mr Ironside introduced Mr Hoyt of New-York, who brought me a Letter from Browere, the man of Plaister Busts— General Brown paid me a morning visit, and Mr Clay brought a draught of a Note to Mr Vaughan the British Minister communicating the Proclamation issued this day, by which the Navigation Acts of 1818 and 1820. are revived— I suggested some softening alterations of the draught, which he adopted— He also left with me a note from the French Minister the Baron de Mareuil, complaining that the discriminating tonnage and impost duties have been levied upon three french vessels which arrived at Savannah, after having touched, and left part of their Cargoes at French West India Islands— There were Letters upon the subject also from the Secretary and Comptroller of the Treasury— My Son Charles has been very unwell these two days with a swollen face, from an ulcerated gum— Dr Huntt came this Eveng and lanced it— He also called upon me, who have been these three days threatened with a cough and sore breast— But it was too slight for the application of any remedy other than Patience— I wrote one Letter, and attempted two others without finishing them—
18. V:15— Cloudy— Rain— Storm.

There came on this morning a heavy storm of rain, which detained me from attendance at Church— I finished a long Letter to A. Gallatin— I write few private Letters, and those under irksome restraints— I can never be sure of writing a line, that will not some day be published by friend or foe— Nor can I write a sentence susceptible of an odious misconstruction, but it will be seized upon and bandied about like a watchword for hatred and derision— This condition of things gives Style the Cramp— I wrote also the weekly Letter to my Son— These at least will escape the torture of the Press— Mr Henry Wheaton called upon me to converse again upon his contemplated Mission as Charge d’Affaires to Denmark— He has yet to obtain the consent of his father; but hopes it will not be withheld— He has read the previous correspondence upon the claims, and I advised him to see and confer with Mr Connell at Philadelphia— He goes for New-York to-morrow— In the afternoon although the Storm continued I attended Church at Mr Baker’s, and heard him from Mark. 13.37— [“]And what I say unto you, I say unto all, Watch”— The auditory was very small, and the text more impressive than the discourse— In the Evening I walked to the Unitarian Church, expecting to hear Mr Little; but there was no service, doubtless owing to the weather— After returning home, I read Mr Huskisson’s Speech in the House of Commons, on the 12th. of May 1826. on the state of the shipping interest, and the Navigation Laws— He admits that in substituting reciprocity, for the old exclusive principle of the Navigation Act, they had proceeded upon compulsion, under the retaliatory discriminating duties of the United States— His whole argument for the adoption of this rule of reciprocity is necessity—imposed by the countervailing regulations of other Countries— Necessity, first to compound with the United States; and next to extend to other Countries the advantages already yielded to them. The further step of taking back from them, that which is now conceded to others, was taken more than two Months after the delivery of this Speech; but the fear and Jealousy of the United States which prompted to that measure are unequivocally disclosed in many passages of the Speech— Charles is better, though still confined to his chamber— The oppression upon my lungs is less than yesterday—but not removed.
19. V:15. symbols Cloud-rain— Caught in Shower.

Dr Watkins called and shewed me a Letter that he had written, in answer to one from B. Estill; concerning a statement made by Alexander Smyth in the Virginia Legislature; that I had offered Carte Blanche to Crawford, at the late Presidential Election, for his support; and that the offer was made by Watkins, through Dickens— The Letter was long, and argumentative— I told the Doctor, I thought it would be better distinctly to declare that he had never been authorised by me to make any such proposal; and never had made any such— Major Nourse brought me two Letters from Lieutenant Vinton, and one from the Indian Agent Crowell shewing difficulties in bringing the suit against the Georgia Surveyors, to a trial in the Circuit Court of the United States— Mr Lindsley came with a new solicitation for a place— Mr Brent informed me that E. Wyer had arrived with the British ratification of the Slave-indemnity Convention— Forrest brought the Commission of a Consul from the king of Saxony at New-York; with an Exequatur to be signed— Mr Baker came to mention a memorial, which the Clerks dismissed from the General Land-Office were inclined to present; asking for a quarter’s pay, from the time of their dismission— He said his Society had agreed to increase his Salary from 6 to 800 dollars— That he should be glad if his brother could obtain a Clerk’s appointment; and he himself would be glad to be chaplain at the Navy-Yard— Mr Webster came to take leave—going to-morrow— Mr Rush about the fray between the two Clerks, Houston and Pottinger— They have settled their dispute, and apologized for their breach of the Peace— Dickson was the keeper of a floating Light in North-Carolina—dismissed by the Collector at Ocracoke and appealing here in vain for redress— I sent him to Mr Pleasonton, for his complaint and his claim— Mr Ironside brought the British ratified Convention, and the Proclamation, which I signed— Mr Clay came for an answer to the French Minister claim of remission to the discriminating duties on three French vessels. I thought it should be simply granted— He had also two Notes from Mr Vaughan with answers which I approved— As also the answer to a complaint from Mr. Rebello. E. Wyer was here in the Evening, the 80th. day since he left Washington for London.
20— IV:50. symbols Sun rose 5:28 = 6.

Commodore Tingey called for a morning visit, having recently recovered from indisposition— General Brown, to introduce a young man, a Son of Paul Beck of Philadelphia; going to England and France to complete his medical education— General Brown goes tomorrow upon his tour to New-Orleans and the West— Mr Clay came with a draught of Instruction to A. Gallatin, to be sent him with the Proclamation restoring the Navigation Acts of 1818 and 1820— He directs him to make no further advance to the British-Government on the subject— But if unexpectedly any should be made on their part, he is authorised to agree upon the basis of either of the two Bills—that were introduced into the Senate, and House of Representatives by the respective Committees of Commerce— Dickson came again with his piteous complaint of having been removed from keeping the floating light, at Ocracroke; but I could only refer him back to Mr Pleasonton— Mr Ironside came for the draughts of Mr Clay’s answer to the Baron de Mareuil; and of his Instruction to Mr Gallatin— I spoke to him to hasten the pamphlet publication of the Laws of the last Session of Congress; and also of the biennial Register— Mr Everett passed an hour with me this Evening— He goes for Boston with his family on Thursday— My Cold, hoarseness, sore breast, and oppression upon the lungs continues unabated.

l.unclear: Herald of Light! whose searching ken descries
The beam first lambent from Night’s regions drear
Minstrel of Morn! whose Clarion sharp and clear
Proclaims the dawning day-star to the skies—
Bird of the brave, whose valiant heart supplies
The beak of Eagles, and the falcon’s Spear
Bird of the lofty port, disdaining fear—
Unvanquish’d Spirit, which oercomes or dies!—
Bird of the faithful! thy resounding horn,
To thee was given the child of man to warn
Of sinking virtue, and of rising day—
Oh! as from morn to morn I hear thy strain
Let the shrill summons call me, not in vain,
With fervour from on high, to Watch and Pray.

div.p: E. Wyer brought me last Evening the Signet ring, which I had requested him to procure for me, in London— The device a very simple one of which a sixpenny Seal had been given me—a Cock—with the motto “Watch”— I wished it in better garb and execution. But the precept of Jesus is to pray as well as watch, and he used the Cock as a Monitor to recall to duty the faithful disciple who denied him at the Crisis of his fate— To fix the fleeting solemnity of these thoughts, I threw them this morning before breakfast into a Sonnet to Chanticleer, which is here in the margin; and of which when I come to be ashamed of the Poetry, I may still adhere to the morality—
21. V:15— Post-Office— Sun rose 5:26 = 5:59. Behind— N.E. Treasy: Chimney.

Mr Southard called this morning: having with Governor Barbour returned yesterday from their Tour to Norfolk and Point Comfort— They had a boisterous time; both going down and returning— But with reference to the business, on which they went are satisfied— Having selected a site for a Navy-Hospital— Genl. Brown came to take leave, and departed on his Southern and Western Tour. Dr. Todsen came full of professions of gratitude for my remission of the pecuniary part of the Sentence against him, and asking for farther favour— I told him I could do nothing for him now— Perhaps in the course of a year or two some occasion might occur when I could serve him: in the meantime I advised him to resort to his profession for a support, and I doubted not that by industry and good conduct he would obtain comfortable subsistence— He thanked me again, and said he would take my advice— And should leave the City in two or three days— Mr Brent came to inform me that there had been by mistake two Appointments of a Consul at Santa Martha, during the late Session of the Senate— The first in December of Seaver. The other in February of Mr Ely— I told him the Commission must be sent to Seaver, and an apology to Mr Ely. Commodore Bainbridge introduced Genl. Gregory and Governor Barbour Mr Asa Rogerson— Both these persons are applicants for the appointment of Collector at Camden North-Carolina in the place of Enoch Sawyer deceased— Mr M’Kenney introduced Bishop M’Kendry of the Methodist Church—and who spoke to me with much feeling of sympathy for the Indians— I returned to Mr R. H. Lee, the Letters from my father, and from Samuel Adams which he had sent me last Summer and had much further conversation with him concerning his projected biography of Arthur Lee— He thought he should treat lightly of Mr Lee’s controversies with S. Deane and Doctor Franklin— I told him of my meeting Jesse Deane in 1824. and that I should be sorry at the publication of anything that would wound his feelings, in regard to his father— I also advised Mr Lee to correspond with Saml. A. Welles which he said he would— Cutts came for the double ration papers; but I had not read them— Schaeffer from Washington County, Maryland, merely to see me; & Mr Clay introduced Mr Picket to me—lately from Kentucky—
22. V:15. symbols Sun rose Fog-veiled

Mrs Adams, with Mary Hellen and Charles left us this morning, on a visit to Baltimore— They accompany Mr and Mrs Everett and Miss Brooks, thus far— Johnson Hellen went with them as far as Vansville—about 16 Miles; and came back to dinner— Mr Southard came to enquire concerning the proceedings of a Court of Enquiry at the Navy-Yard at Brooklyne New-York, on complaints against Brevet Lieutenant Coll. R. Smith the papers are very voluminous and I had not read them— Mr Wirt, Attorney General, spoke of certain proceedings of the U.S. District Attorney in Ohio Benham, concerning obstructions to the Navigation of the Sciote river, wherein Benham had commenced a prosecution without authority; and then discontinued it, on pretence of Instructions from Mr Wirt, which he never gave— I had heard complaints against the Prosecution before—but nothing of the discontinuance— Mr Wirt said he would write to Benham about it, and inform me of the result— He recommended to me T. Randall for judge of the Middle District of Florida, in the Event of the Office being vacated by judge Woodward— Clement was a poor Projector, who has invented a hollow sphere, to serve as a substitute for a magnetic compass near the Pole, where he says the Needle will not traverse— He wanted assistance to make his globe which I could not bestow. Mr Rush brought a complaint from the Comptroller of the Treasury, against a Collector in Maryland, named Ennals, who retains too much money in his hands, and whom it may be necessary to dismiss— I desired that warning might first be given him— Mr Rush expressed some fears for the Revenue of the year, owing to the interdict on the British Colonial trade— Governor Barbour brought a budget of papers concerning the contract of J. Bruce for removing obstructions in the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers— Also the proceedings of Court Martial upon eighteen Cadets at West-Point— One of them is a brother to Mr Berrien the Senator from Georgia, who wishes to present an argument against the Sentence of the Court— I consented to receive it— Mr Catlett of Alexandria called to repeat a recommendation that a Son of Mr John Duer of New-York; and a son of a Mr Robertson, both Grandsons of Lord Stirling, might be received as Cadets at West Point— Mr Catlett spoke of the political influence of the Duer family; and their impression that I had neglected my friends in New-York.
23. IV:45— symbols Sun rose beclouded—

Mr Graham left with me a printed document of the late House of Representatives, relating to the resale of relinquished Lands in the State of Alabama; containing a draught of a Bill sent by him to the Committee on Public Lands, but which did not pass the two Houses of Congress— The Delegation from the State in both Houses were earnestly desirous that no Sales should be made but Mr Graham says the Postponement will cause a great deficiency in the proceeds of the Lands estimated at the commencement of the last Session of Congress— General Macomb came and took from the files of the Court-Martial proceedings on the Cadets, the sheets containing the trial of Mr Berrien’sbrother— Mr Forrest came for the Exequatur’s for two Consuls of the king of Saxony, which had been sent me to sign, and which he took. John Mason is Secretary to the Legation to Mexico— He came home as a Messenger, with the Treaty concluded by Mr Poinsett, and now asks a furlough for eight Months— He is on the brink of Marriage, and has important private concerns which require his attention— I told him that these furloughs from Service abroad were inconvenient to the publick, and distasteful to the Government—but he said Edward Tayloe was with Mr Poinsett, performing entirely to his satisfaction all the duties of a Secretary of Legation; entirely competent to them, esteemed in the Country and possessed familiarly of the Spanish Language. He said also that he should expect of course that his Salary would be suspended while his leave of absence should be continued— I finally told him that I would consider of his application and comply with it, if I could consistently with my duty to the Public. Dr. Todsen came to ask me, if I was willing that he should publish a written opinion signed by E. Livingston against the proceedings of his Court Martial; and also a note stating that when I approved the proceedings of the Court-martial against him, I had not seen the Letter of Bishop Dubourg, and General Gaines in his favour— I told him no such note could be published, as the fact was otherwise— And as to Mr Livingston’s opinion he might publish it if he pleased; but I thought it would rather injure than serve him— Governor Kent called for a morning visit— Mr Clay read me a Letter from Jabez D. Hamond at Albany, and left with me one from a Coll. Thompson in Kentucky— He had also a draught of a Letter to L. Cheves requesting him to see that the papers of the Slave Commission should be delivered over to the new Commission— E. Wyer dined and spent part of the Evening with us.
24. IV:30. symbols Sun rose V:20:15 = 5:56.

Mr Southard came with a Letter from Loammi Baldwin, agreeing to accept the appointment of Engineer for constructing the Dry Docks at Charlestown and at Gosport, under the act of the last Session of Congress for the gradual improvement of the Navy— There was some question of details upon the terms of his engagement, but none that cannot easily be adjusted— He proposes that his two brothers should be employed, as assistants with him— Mr Southard had also a Letter from R. S. Garnett, late a member of Congress from Virginia, soliciting for a passage in some one of the Public Ships, if it can be granted without impinging upon State rights— Garnett was a lively, sensible, and somewhat eccentric Virginian, who was all but demolished three years ago by a fever— Never was the vital spark nearer extinction and yet kept alive— He was nine tenths dead when elected to the late Congress— He now declines a re-election, and wishes to go to Sea in a public Ship, for the recovery of his health— The res angusta domi will not admit he says of his going at his own expence— Mr Southard came afterwards a second time to make enquiries concerning the Sentences upon the trial of the Cadets— The father of one of them, Stocker, has written to him asking his interposition in behalf of his Son— He was sentenced to be dismissed— I had not read the proceedings but intimated to Mr. Southard that it would be well to give an interlocutory answer to Mr Stocker— Interferences of fathers and members of Congress with Courts Martial, being in no wise favourable to the support of discipline. Mr Randolph came upon a plan for a reorganization of the Militia, of this District, with a view to the promotion of Brigadier General Walter Smith of Georgetown to the Rank of a Major General— I promised Major Randolph to examine the papers, and see him again upon the Subject— Mr Rush brought the Statements of the balance in the Treasury, and the estimate of receipts and expenditures till the first of July, with a view to determine, how much of the principal of the public debt may then be paid off. His opinion fixes upon five Millions, with which my own coincides— He is very apprehensive of a defalcation in the revenue, from the interdiction of the British Colonial Trade— And there is already a falling off from the estimates in the proceeds of Sales of the Public Lands— Mrs AdamsMary Hellen and Charles, returned this Afternoon from their tour to Baltimore. My Catarrhal Cold is yet extremely troublesome.
25. V— Round Tyber Square. Sun rose 5:18:15 = 5:54

Heard Little. Isaiah 59:15.— “And the Lord saw it, and it displeased him[”]— The discourse chiefly consisted of an enumeration of the vices and passions, of men, which it displeases the Lord to see— Afternoon at St. John’s Church— Heard Hawley—from 1. Corinthians 16.20. “Greet ye one another with an holy kiss. The Salutation of me— Paul with mine own hand— If any man love not the Lord Jesus Christ, let him be Anathema Maran-atha. The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you. My love be with you all in Christ Jesus Amen.” Why all this was given for a text did not appear. The Sermon was all upon the Anathema Maran-atha. Heard Little again in the Evening from Matthew 6–7.8— [“]But when ye pray use not vain repetition, as the heathen do: for they think that they shall be heard for their much speaking— Be not yet therefore like unto them: for your Father knows what things ye have need of before ye ask him.”— Mr Little considers the liturgy of the Church of England as liable to the objection of using vain repetitions in prayers. After returning home I signed a pile of Blank Mediterranean Passports which was all I could do— The Catarrh with which I have been labouring these ten days has been more troublesome the last two Nights than before— Last Night it bereft me almost entirely of sleep, which has left me this day drowsy and disqualified for useful labour— I wrote to my Son George, and journalised for yesterday; but could make little progress in writing. The Vegetation of Spring is advancing— The weeping willows are in leaf; and the Lombardy Poplars are now shedding their blossoms which are disposed like a brush round a stalk 2 1/2 inches in length flexible as a worm— This is also the time of setting out young trees, which they are doing in the avenues round the public buildings— I have a great mass of papers before me to read—being proceedings of Court Martials on the Cadets and of a Court of Inquiry upon Coll. Smith of the Marine Corps, at New-York— This perusal has been suspended this day for other occupation.
26. V. symbols Cloudy.
